<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 720, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the forces supporting a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|> Do **not** attempt to change the position of either newton meter by adjusting the positions of the loops of thread attached to them. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 863, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 405, 532, 425]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 144, 456]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 803, 456]]<|/det|> Move the \(1.00 \text{N}\) load to a distance \(d = 25.0 \text{cm}\) from the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 920, 503]]<|/det|> Move one stand slightly, if necessary, so that the newton meters are as near to vertical as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 515, 920, 548]]<|/det|> Read, and record in Table 1.1, the value \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) on newton meter P and the value \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) on newton meter Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 819, 579]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for \(d = 35.0 \text{cm}, d = 45.0 \text{cm}, d = 55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(d = 65.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 593, 541, 610]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 624, 645, 775]]<|/det|>
\(d/\text {cm}\)\(F_{\mathrm {p}}/\mathrm {N}\)\(F_{\mathrm {Q}}/\mathrm {N}\)

35.0
45.0
55.0
65.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 715, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 747, 106]]<|/det|>
The resistance of an LDR changes as the intensity of light falling on it varies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 675, 139]]<|/det|>
The resistance \(R\) of the LDR is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 841, 166]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the LDR and \(I\) is the current in the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 850, 212]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the light intensity affects the resistance of an LDR. You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 398, 244]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 225, 259]]<|/det|>
an LDR

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 700, 275]]<|/det|>
equipment to connect the circuit, part of which is shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 388, 291]]<|/det|>
a lamp with a power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 322, 321]]<|/det|>
